div.p: C[oelius] S[ecundus] C[urio] through Christ Jesus sends greetings.

I wrote to you recently, most illustrious and esteemed lord, about a matter which you yourself know; I wrote, however, as to a friend, a brother, and a prudent man, and I do not think I am mistaken in this opinion; yet I seem to sense something here and I fear that somehow, without your fault, this matter has reached the ears of those people. Therefore, I am compelled to be anxious until this doubt is removed by you.

I therefore beg you, my most excellent lord and brother, to write to me as soon as possible, whether you think it could have been possible for what I wrote to you about this matter to have leaked from there to here.

I indeed thought that you would do something about this matter with the brothers there, but with my name suppressed, so that I would not incur the hatred of those people; for you yourself know very well how irritable and implacable they are. Farewell with all your family.

It has been written to our merchants here from Antwerp that thirty ships, in which there were both soldiers and stipends, which were heading from Spain to Marseille, have perished in a storm, and likewise eight ships, which were carrying gold from the New Indies to Spain, have also sunk in the Ocean.
To the most illustrious and excellent man, Lord Heinrich Bullinger, the most vigilant Antistes of the Church of Zürich, his most esteemed lord. In Zürich.
